questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with purulent vaginal discharge associated with fever, malaise, and inguinal pain. A Pap smear revealed the following findings.  What is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given image of Pap smear shows cells with ground glass nuclei, viral inclusions, multinucleation, and margination of chromatin. These findings are characteristic of herpes simplex infection.

Some infections of the female genital tract and their diagnostic features are given below:

Infections Diagnostic features
Herpes simplex

Ground glass nuclei with 3M's:

  • Multinucleation
  • Margination of chromatin
  • Molding of nuclei
Molluscum contagiosum Pearly dome-shaped papule containing cells with cytoplasmic viral inclusions
Trichomonas vaginalis

Strawberry cervix; pear-shaped flagellated organism.
Gardnerella vaginalis Clue cells - squamous cells covered with a shaggy coating coccobacilli
Candida Pseudospores and filamentous fungal hyphae

questions.text: What are the cystic remnants of mesonephric ducts in the cervix and vagina called?
questions.solution:
Cystic remnants of mesonephric ducts in the cervix and vagina are termed Gartner duct cysts.

The mesonephric (Wolffian) ducts normally regress in females. Its remnants may persist into adult life as epithelial inclusions adjacent to the ovaries, tubes, and uterus. In the cervix and vagina, these ducts may be cystic and are termed Gartner duct cysts.

The following images show the embryological development of the mesonephric duct and its persistence into adult life.

questions.text: The following histological image depicts a pathology in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows benign papillary projections covered with columnar secretory epithelium and underlying myoepithelial cells. These are commonly seen in papillary hidradenoma of the vulva.

It presents as a sharply circumscribed nodule, most commonly on the labia majora or interlabial folds. Like the breast, the vulva also contains modified apocrine sweat glands. Its histologic appearance is identical to that of intraductal papilloma of the breast.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with a mass protruding from the anterior vaginal wall that appears like grape clusters. Histopathological examination reveals tadpole cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (sarcoma botryoides).

It is an uncommon vaginal tumor composed of malignant embryonal rhabdomyoblasts. It is most frequently found in infants and in children < 5 years of age. They are locally invasive tumors that cause death by penetration into the peritoneal cavity or by obstruction of the urinary tract.

Grossly, polypoid, rounded, bulky masses that appear like grape clusters can be seen. On microscopy, small tumor cells with oval nuclei, and small protrusions of cytoplasm from one end resembling a tennis racket (tadpole cells) can be seen. Beneath the vaginal epithelium, the tumor cells are crowded in a cambium layer, in the dermis.

questions.text:
Which of the following is false regarding precursor squamous epithelial lesions of the cervix?

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

choices.text: LSIL progress directly to invasive carcinoma
LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs
HPV-16 is the most common HPV type in both LSIL and HSIL
They progress to invasive carcinoma over many years

questions.solution:
Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL) does not progress directly to invasive carcinoma. They initially progress to a high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), then invasive carcinoma.

The WHO currently recommends a 2-tier system of classification for cervical lesions - low and high-grade intraepithelial lesions (LSIL and HSIL). HPV-16 is the most common HPV type associated with both LSIL and HSIL

LSILs are 10 times more common than HSILs.  Most of these lesions regress spontaneously. Progression to invasive carcinoma is unpredictable and can take place over years.

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: What is the most common type of human papilloma virus causing cervical carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus (HPV)-16 is the most common type of HPV causing cervical carcinoma. It accounts for almost 60% of cervical cancer cases.

The ability of HPV to act as a carcinogen depends on the viral proteins E6 and E7. These proteins interfere with the activity of tumor-suppressor proteins that regulate cell growth and survival.

  • E6 - binds with p53 gene and promote its degradation
  • E7 - binds with RB gene and promotes its degradation

Related Pearl: Human Papilloma Virus (HPV) and Associated Lesions

HPV serotype Lesions
HPV 1,2,3,4
  • Common warts (verruca vulgaris, plantar wart)
HPV 6 and 11
  • Condyloma acuminatum (genital warts)
  • Sinonasal papilloma
  • Squamous papilloma of the larynx
HPV 16
  • LSIL, HSIL, carcinoma cervix
  • Vulval carcinoma
  • Bowen disease (Carcinoma in situ of male external genitalia)
  • Oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma
HPV 18
  • LSIL, HSIL, Carcinoma of the cervix
  • Carcinoma of the anogenital region
HPV 5 and 8
  • Squamous cell carcinoma of the skin in epidermodysplasia verruciformis patients
   

 

LSIL: Low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

HSIL: High-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text: A young woman comes to the gynecology OPD for cervical cancer screening. What is the staining technique used for this?
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer screening test, commonly known as Pap smear, is stained using the Papanicolaou method.

The time for initiating Pap smear screening is 21 years, regardless of the age of first sexual intercourse. 

The sample is collected using Ayre's spatula and endocervical brush. 2 samples are taken:

  • 1st slide - prepared from a sample taken from portio vaginalis of the cervix
  • 2nd slide - prepared from the sample taken from the endocervix (transformation zone)

95% ethanol is used as a fixative.

It is a highly specific test. Colposcopic examination and biopsy are recommended in case of abnormal Pap smear results.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about type I endometrial carcinoma?

choices.text: It is associated with obesity and diabetes
Smoking is a high risk factor
It is caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation

questions.solution:
Smoking is strongly associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma of the ovary, but not endometrial carcinoma.

Endometrial carcinoma is the most common invasive cancer of the female genital tract. Type 1 endometrial carcinoma shows endometrioid morphology and is associated with:

  • Unopposed estrogen exposure (endometrial hyperplasia)
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hypertension

PTEN tumor-suppressor gene is mutated in approximately 20% of endometrial hyperplasias.

Genomic sequencing of endometrial carcinoma has revealed 4 major molecular subtypes of endometrioid and serous carcinomas:

  • Ultramutated/ POLE tumors - mutations in DNA polymerase ε (POLE)
  • Hypermutated/ MSI (microsatellite instability) tumors - mutations involving mismatch repair genes
  • Copy number low/ MSS (microsatellite stable) tumors - mutations involving the PI3K/AKT pathway
  • Copy number high/ serous-like tumors - TP53 mutations and numerous genomic copy number variants

Related Pearl: Types of endometrial carcinoma

Characteristics Type 1 Type 2
Age 55–65 yr 65–75 yr
Clinical setting Unopposed estrogen
Obesity
Hypertension
Diabetes		 Atrophy
Thin physique
Morphology Endometrioid Serous
Clear Cell
Mixed mullerian tumor

intraepithelial carcinoma

PIK3CA (PI3K)

lymphatic spread

questions.text: Which of the following is not a criterion to distinguish leiomyosarcoma from leiomyoma?
questions.solution:
The size of the tumor is not a criterion to distinguish between leiomyosarcoma and leiomyoma.

The following features are seen in leiomyosarcomas:

  • Mitotic index - ≥10 mitoses / 10 hpf 
  • Nuclear atypia - in the presence of nuclear atypia, 5 mitoses / 10 hpf 
  • Tumor cell necrosis - 
    • Characterized by an abrupt transition from viable to non-viable areas
    • Within the necrotic zones, atypical cells can be seen

questions.text: Histopathological examination of an ovarian mass sent to the pathology department revealed the following. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: It is more common in women with low parity
The pathogenesis is related to family history and heritable mutations
High-grade tumors are associated with TP53 mutations

questions.solution:
The given image denotes Psammoma bodies which are a histopathological finding seen in ovarian papillary serous cystadenoma and cystadenocarcinoma. These tumors are most commonly bilateral.

The majority of serous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline. But the serous carcinomas of the ovary include the most common malignant tumors of the ovary. 

Nulliparity, family history, and heritable mutations play a role in the development of these tumors. Mutations in the oncogenes KRAS, BRAF, or ERBB2 result in low-grade tumors, and mutation in TP53 is associated with high-grade tumors. 

There is a higher frequency of carcinoma in women with low parity. Women on oral contraceptive pills or those who have undergone tubal ligation are at a lower risk. The marker for ovarian tumors is CA-125.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding mucinous tumors of the ovary?

choices.text: It occurs principally in middle adult life
Mutation of the KRAS proto-oncogene is seen

questions.solution:
The vast majority of mucinous tumors of the ovary are benign or borderline tumors (not malignant).

It occurs principally in middle adult life and is rare before puberty and after menopause. The surface of the ovary is rarely involved, they are rarely bilateral. It is associated with the mutation of KRAS proto-oncogene. 

Grossly it is multiloculated and filled with sticky, gelatinous fluid (rich in glycoproteins).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman underwent an evaluation for an abdominal mass. A laparotomy was decided upon for the removal of the mass. The gross appearance of the mass is as follows. Histopathological examination revealed no malignant change. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and image showing unilocular cystic space containing hair and sebaceous material are suggestive of mature teratoma.

Dermoid cysts or mature teratomas are benign tumors, usually found in young women during the active reproductive years. It is bilateral in 10% to 15% of cases.

Microscopically, the cyst wall is composed of tissues from all 3 germ layers. This includes stratified squamous epithelium, with underlying sebaceous glands, hair shafts, and other skin adnexal structures. Sometimes cartilage, bone, thyroid, and neural tissue can be seen.

About 1% of the dermoids undergo malignant transformation, most commonly to squamous cell carcinoma. It can also transform into other cancers (e.g., thyroid carcinoma, melanoma).

The component tissue of immature malignant teratomas resembles embryonal and immature fetal tissue. It often consists of primitive neuroepithelial cells. The tumor is found chiefly in prepubertal adolescents and young women, the mean age being 18 years.

Monodermal or specialized teratomas:

  • Struma ovarii - composed entirely of mature thyroid tissue, which may be functional and cause hyperthyroidism.
  • Ovarian carcinoid - arises from intestinal tissue, may be functional causing carcinoid syndrome in the absence of hepatic metastasis

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors
  • Clear cell 
  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure
  • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumors

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary
VI. Miscellaneous tumors
VII. Secondary (metastatic) tumors
VIII. Tumor-like conditions

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with a history of abdominal pain and distension of abdomen. Ultrasound imaging revealed tumor in the right ovary. Serum level of inhibin was raised. The histopathology of the tumor is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.

Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles. Additionally, small, cuboidal to polygonal cells are seen which may grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands. 

Granulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian follicle. It can be of adult and juvenile types. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with this tumor.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in most adult granulosa cell tumors.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Serous tumors
  • Mucinous tumors
  • Endometrioid tumors

  • Brenner tumors (transitional cell tumors)
  • Seromucinous
  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)
  • Embryonal carcinoma
  • Polyembryoma
  • Non-gestational choriocarcinoma
  • Teratoma (Mature/immature)
  • Mixed forms

IV. Gonadoblastoma

  • Pure

V. Soft tissue tumors not specific to ovary

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl, who is yet to attain her menarche, presents with an ovarian mass. Her serum biomarkers are normal except for elevated AFP. Staging laparotomy was performed and the histopathological image is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the histopathological image showing Schiller Duval bodies are suggestive of endodermal sinus tumors. It is also known as yolk sac tumor.

The Schiller-Duval body is a glomerulus-like structure composed of a central blood vessel enveloped by tumor cells within a space that is also lined by tumor cells.

It is the second most common malignant tumor of germ cell origin. It is a unilateral tumor usually affecting children or young women.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text:
Which of the following are sex cord-stromal tumors?
  1. Brenner tumor
  2. Granulosa cell tumor
  3. Sertoli cell tumour
  4. Fibroma
  5. Dysgerminoma
questions.solution:
Sex cord-stromal tumors include the following:

  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Fibroma

Brenner tumor is an epithelial tumor and dysgerminoma is a germ cell tumor.

Related Pearl: WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumors

I.  Epithelial tumors (most common)

  • Undifferentiated carcinoma
II. Sex cord-stromal tumors:
  • Pure stromal cell tumors- Fibroma, Thecoma, Leydig cell tumor, Steroid cell tumor
  • Pure sex cord tumors- Granulosa cell tumor (Adult/Juvenile), Sertoli cell tumor
  • Mixed sex cord-stromal tumors- Sertoli–Leydig cell tumors

III. Germ cell tumors:

  • Dysgerminoma
  • Endodermal sinus tumor (Yolk sac tumor)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presented with bilateral adnexal masses. Histopathological examination of the resected specimen showed sheets of mucin-producing signet-ring cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of metastatic carcinoma of the ovary or Krukenberg tumor. 

It can arise from primary carcinomas of the stomach (most common), colon, appendix, and breast (invasive lobular carcinoma). It is often bilateral and on microscopy shows mucin-laden signet-ring cells with eccentric hyperchromatic nuclei.

Metastatic tumors of the ovary include:

  • Tumors of Müllerian origin (most common) - the uterus, fallopian tube, contralateral ovary, or pelvic peritoneum
  • Tumors of extra-Müllerian tumors - breast and gastrointestinal tract carcinomas
  • Pseudomyxoma peritonei - derived from appendiceal tumors
  • Krukenberg tumor

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was diagnosed with molar pregnancy and underwent suction and evacuation. The resected specimen is shown below. Histopathological examination revealed thin-walled, cystic structures consisting of hydropic villi with extensive trophoblastic proliferation along its entire circumference. Immunohistochemistry was negative for p57. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: The genetic material is completely maternally derived
Embryo dies very early in development and therefore is usually not identified
It is associated with a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and image showing grapelike vesicles are suggestive of a complete mole. It results from the fertilization of an egg that has lost its female chromosomes, and as a result, the genetic material is completely paternally derived.

The pathogenesis of complete mole is as follows:

  • Androgenesis (most common) - 46XX karyotype stemming from the duplication of the genetic material of 1 sperm
  • Dispermy - 46XX or 46XY karyotype due to fertilization of an empty egg by 2 sperms

Microscopically, thin-walled, cystic, grapelike structures consisting of hydropic villi are seen. Trophoblastic proliferation involving the entire circumference of the villi is seen.

The embryo dies very early in development and, therefore, is usually not identified. Patients have a 2.5% risk of subsequent choriocarcinoma and a 15% risk of the persistent or invasive mole.

The following image shows the pathogenesis of molar pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with a positive pregnancy test presented with vaginal bleeding in the first trimester.  On examination, grape-like vesicles were noted in the vagina. A transvaginal ultrasound revealed the presence of fetal tissues. A suction evacuation was performed. What is the most likely karyotype of the evacuated material?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with grape-like vesicles in the vagina and the presence of fetal tissues on transvaginal ultrasound are suggestive of partial mole. The karyotype in a partial mole is triploid (e.g., 69XXY) or occasionally tetraploid (92XXXY).

It results from the fertilization of an egg with 2 sperms. There is an increased risk of persistent molar disease but it is not associated with choriocarcinoma.

Given below is an image showing the karyotype of molar pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: What is the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Lungs are the most common site of metastasis in gestational choriocarcinoma. 

It is followed by the vagina, brain, liver, bone, and kidney in descending order of frequency.

Gestational choriocarcinomas are malignant neoplasm of trophoblastic cells derived from a previously normal or abnormal pregnancy, such as an extrauterine ectopic pregnancy. The hCG levels are elevated to levels above those encountered in hydatidiform moles. It shows hematogenous spread. It is rapidly invasive and metastasizes widely.

Gestational choriocarcinomas are chemosensitive whereas non-gestational choriocarcinomas are chemoresistant.

questions.text: The genetic profile of malignant mixed Müllerian tumors resembles that of:
questions.solution:
Malignant mixed Müllerian tumors (MMMTs) are carcinosarcomas whose genetic profile closely resembles endometrial carcinomas.

They involve mutations in the same genes - PTEN, TP53, and PIK3CA. The usual genetic alterations found in sarcomas are absent in MMMTs.

MMMTs are endometrial adenocarcinomas with malignant mesenchymal components. The mesenchymal component may resemble uterine mesenchymal elements (stromal sarcoma, leiomyosarcoma) or contain heterologous malignant cell types (striated muscle, cartilage, adipose tissue, and bone).

It occurs in postmenopausal women and presents with bleeding. It is associated with a poor outcome.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the components of Meig's syndrome?
  1. Ascites
  2. Dysgerminoma of ovary
  3. Right-sided hydrothorax
  4. Fibroma of ovary
  5. Hydropneumothorax
questions.solution:
Meigs' syndrome triad includes the following:

  1. Solid benign ovarian tumor (fibroma)
  2. Right-sided hydrothorax
  3. Ascites - disappears after the removal of the tumor

Pseudo-Meigs' syndrome is characterized by the following:

  1. Non-malignant ascites
  2. Pleural effusion 
  3. Pelvic tumors - other than solid benign ovarian tumors

Note: Ovarian fibroma is also associated with nevoid basal cell carcinoma. This association is known as Gorlin syndrome.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman was operated for an ovarian mass and the sample was sent for histopathological examination. The findings are given below. Which of the following is false about the given condition?

choices.text: It expresses OCT-3, OCT4, and NANOG
It occurs in patients with gonadal dysgenesis

questions.solution:
The given histopathological image shows large cells with clear cytoplasm (fried egg appearance), tumor cells arranged in sheets, and cords of fibrous stroma infiltrated by lymphocytes. These findings are suggestive of dysgerminoma. It is highly responsive to radiotherapy.

Dysgerminomas are the ovarian counterparts of testicular seminoma. They may occur in childhood, but most commonly occur in the 2-3rd decades. It may occur in patients with gonadal dysgenesis, including pseudohermaphroditism. The majority of these tumors are unilateral. They express OCT-3, OCT4, and NANOG.

All dysgerminomas are malignant, but the degree of histologic atypia is variable. Only about one-third of these lesions are aggressive. These neoplasms are responsive to chemoradiation, and overall survival exceeds 80%.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma
